US MARKET WRAP: Stocks shrug-off Mueller headlines, DXY snaps 4 negative days but ends week lower
content:
EQUITIES: SPX +0.1% at 2739, DJI +0.1% at 25281, NDX -0.1% at 6785
Top sectors: Healthcare +0.9%, Telecoms +0.9%, Utilities +0.9%
Bottom sectors: Cons Disc -0.3%, Materials -0.1% Energy -0.1%

SPX prints its sixth straight day of gains, as traders question whether the recent VIX-inspired sell-off can actually be considered anything close to “market turmoil,” though some traders still note that the ES is yet to fully pare back those losses, and reclaim the 2785 level. The risk tone was once again firm on Friday, until headlines hit stating that Special Counsel Mueller had indicted 13 Russians and three entities with regards to interference in the 2016 Presidential Election. At the time, stock indices were losing steam, with ES March’18 contract struggling to negotiate the 2750 handle, and the news brought out the sellers. The indictments contained no allegations that an American citizen was knowingly involved in US election meddling, and after stocks skidded lower into negative territory, buyers emerged around the key 2725 level, and stocks once again found themselves in positive territory, though the social media names weighed on the Nasdaq, which finished red. 

TREASURIES:  US T-Note futures (March 2018) settle 4 ticks higher at 120-18+

The US Treasury complex was immune to headlines that Special Counsel Mueller had indicted 13 Russians and three entities for meddling in the 2016 US Presidential Election. The curve was slightly higher pre-market, though buyers emerged for a second day, with no specific news catalyst. Some had rationalised the moves by suggesting that US Treasuries were oversold in many places, from a technical perspective. Either way, the net impact was narrowing in major curve spreads (2s10s -c4bps, 2s30s -c3bps, hough 5s30s was up slightly) 

FOREX: DXY ends the week 1.5% lower

Ahead of the long weekend, the USD snapped its run of four straight days of losses, ending the week with a positive day, but still looks set to close the week with a c1.5% loss. After this week’s CPI and retail sales data, there hasn’t been anything specific for FX traders to latch on to, and data and politics have generally played second fiddle to position adjusting. Many now are resuming the narrative of a weaker dollar based on expected twin deficits, trade protectionism, and other central banks playing catch-up to the US tightening cycle – helping their currencies appreciate – all amid a background of decent global growth. EUR gave up the 1.25 handle, GBP gave up 1.41, and JPY climbed back above 106 after falling to 105.50 overnight. 

CRUDE: WTI futures settle 34 cents higher at $61.68 per barrel; Brent futures settle 51 cents higher at $64.84 per barrel

The crude complex was shaken in the early part of the week by bearish updates from the EIA, IEA as well as OPEC, whose forecasts all showed that global supply growth was set to outpace demand growth. However, at the end of the week – and looking with a wider lens – crude has generally looked-through the news, in part supported by comments from Saudi Arabia and Russia (Saudis set to trim production next month), but mainly taking its cue from ‘recovering’ global risk sentiment and optimism about global growth prospects, as well as the USD weakness.

subject: Update: US Commerce Department to delay its steel and aluminum announcement to 12.00ET/17.00GMT
FX Weekly Wrap: Dollar bears baited, but grizzly week for the Greenback overall
content: It’s hard to pinpoint a catalyst, but technicals and positioning certainly played a role in the Usd revival at the end of a bleak week. The DXY found some traction around a key chart Fib at 88.250 and gradually gained recovery momentum to reclaim 89.000 and a bit more before fading again. It remains to be seen how specs are positioned, but a still heavily oversold Dollar may have seen shorts pare back. Regardless, Usd/Jpy did not claim another big figure scalp on the downside having tested 105.50 vs 109.00 approximately on Monday, but key will be a close above or below 106.50 from circa 106.25 currently. Eur/Usd is roughly 100 pips off its 1.2555 peak, but stops touted on a break of 1.2450 have not pushed the pair convincingly back below the 200 MMA (1.2453). Cable has pulled back further, but not below 1.4000 and Usd/Cad has topped out around 1.2550 despite weak Canadian data in the form of manufacturing sales. Usd/Chf has bounced relatively firmly above 0.9250 as Wall Street reclaimed early losses, while Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd retreat from near 0.8000 and 0.7400+ highs with the latter not just capped by 0.8000 resistance, but also a key tech level just below (0.7992). In short, the buck may have found some traction ahead of the long US holiday weekend, but it is far too premature to call an end to the latest losing streak or any turnaround in fortunes.

subject: Atlanta Fed GDPNow Q1 3.2% (Prev. 3.2%)
DEBT UPDATE: core bonds continue to claw back losses
content: Firmer than expected US data has not deflected fixed from rebounding further, but the Usd is gaining more recovery momentum or at least continue to consolidate after its latest slide in the FX markets. Bunds and Gilts have now been as high as 158.50 and 121.30 respectively (+60 and +71 ticks from previous Eurex and Liffe closes), with the former now within (easier) striking distance of the next ‘bullish’ technical objective at 158.65. UST futures are all above par, but with the flatter bias remaining, while the Greenback has managed to recoup more lost ground and unwind more of its underperformance vs G10 and other rivals – DXY not far from 89.000 vs circa 88.250 at worst.

subject: Deere & Co (DE) Q1 Adj. EPS USD 1.31vs. Exp. USD 1.20, revenue USD 6.91bln vs. Exp. USD 6.42bln
DAILY US OPENING NEWS:  European equities (Eurostoxx 50 +0.9%) trade higher across the board after what was another firm close on Wall Street
content:
16th December 2017

  • European equities (Eurostoxx 50 +0.9%) trade higher across the board after what was another firm close on Wall Street
  • In FX markets, the Jpy’s flight continues to compound the Dollar’s plight amongst G10 majors
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US building permits, housing starts, Uni. Of Michigan

ASIA

Stock markets were quiet in Asia with most the region away for Lunar New Year holiday, while the few bourses which were open seemed to have joined in on the celebratory tone and initially took impetus from a 5th consecutive win streak on Wall St. As such, ASX 200 (-0.1%) was positive for most the day with earnings in focus, although upside was capped and later reversed amid profit taking in mining-related sectors. Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) continued to defy the recent JPY strength and outperformed as participants widely anticipated the Japanese government nominations for Kuroda to serve a 2nd term and 2 more doves for the Deputy Governor roles, while markets in China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Singapore were among the mass holiday closures. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher as Japanese yields retreated across the curve and which also followed the gains in USTs during the prior session, while the enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated bonds failed to impact prices with the results broadly inline with the prior.

Japan submitted nomination for BoJ Governor Kuroda to stay on for another term, while it also nominated reflationist academic Wakatabe and BoJ’s Amamiya as Deputy Governors. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

White House urged the House to advance the Goodlatte immigration proposal after 4 bills were defeated in the Senate. (Newswires)

Former Trump campaign adviser Gates is said to be nearing a plea deal with Special Counsel Mueller with negotiations having taken around a month already. (Newswires)

The UK’s IOD has put forward a bespoke Brexit solution which it believes will protect manufacturers from customs chaos but also allow the UK to strike independent trade deals. (Telegraph)

UK Retail Sales MM (Jan) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. -1.5%, Rev. 1.5%)

UK Retail Sales YY (Jan) 1.6% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 1.4%, Rev. 1.5%)

UK Retail Sales Ex-Fuel MM (Jan) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. -1.6%, Rev. -1.5%)

UK Retail Sales Ex-Fuel YY (Jan) 1.5% vs. Exp. 2.5% (Prev. 1.3%)

CENTAL BANKS

ECB’s Coeure says interest rates will not rise before bond buying ends; also stating that policy makers are unanimous. Policy language to be discussed in early 2018. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities (Eurostoxx 50 +0.9%) trade higher across the board after what was another firm close on Wall Street (S&P 500 +1.2%). All ten sectors trade in positive territory with outperformance in utility names following stellar earnings from EDF (+6.2%), subsequently dragging other names in the space higher. Elsewhere, energy names are performing well as prices remain supported by the softer USD. This morning’s equity newsflow has been largely dominated by a busy slate of earnings from the likes of Renault (+3.1%), Eni (+1.5%), Allianz (-0.7%) and Vivendi (-5.8%) which have provided a bulk of the focus for traders thus far.

FX

The Jpy’s flight continues to compound the Dollar’s plight amongst G10 majors, but the Greenback remains a broader loser as EM currencies and commodities also prosper amidst the latest Usd sell-off. The DXY only just held above major Fib support at 88.250 overnight as Usd/Jpy selling eased up ahead of 105.50. However, only mild verbal acknowledgment of the largely one-way tide from Japanese officials, and no mention of intervention inspired a tame or token rebound to around 106.00 before the slide resumed. The Aud and Nzd are now looking at 0.8000 and 0.7450 vs their US counterpart, while the Eur has eclipsed its previous 2018 peak to trade just above 1.2550 and a few pips over the 1.2551 100 MMA having surpassed the 200 version (1.2453) on the way. Stops are said to waiting on a break of 1.2570, ahead of the next upside tech target at 1.2598, but a decent 1.2550 option expiry (1 bn) may keep the pair in check. Cable has now advanced through 1.4100 and almost hit 1.4144, with price action relatively contained following this morning’s below-expectation UK retail sales release. Usd/Chf is seriously testing the 0.9200 handle, with 0.9175 in sight.   

Japan's Chief Govt. spokesman said the FX market has shown one-sided moves recently. He added no need to change government stance on FX however no comments were added on whether appropriate measures include FX intervention. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Gilts and Bunds squeezing higher again as more short positions are pared or liquidated ahead of the long US holiday weekend, and with buyers getting extra incentive from sub-forecast UK retail sales. The core 10 year bonds have now been up to 121.01 and 158.20 respectively, +42 and +32 ticks on the day, with some also pointing to bullish chart impulses amidst several gaps being filled in the process. On that note, the Eurex benchmark will now be eyeing Wednesday’s session best at 158.38, while its UK peer needs to make a clean break above 121.00 before challenging the next tech resistance levels. Turning to US Treasuries, the curve flattening theme is still prevalent as the short end continues to underperform on the hawkish Fed rate hike vibe following latest data showing an acceleration in wages, factory gate and consumer prices.

COMMODITIES

In the commodities complex, WTI and Brent crude futures continue to benefit from the softer USD with prices eyeing USD 62.00bbl and USD 65.00bbl to the upside respectively despite forecasts for a continuation of surging US production and a slew of markets currently shut in Asia; Baker Hughes set to take focus in the latter stages of the session. In metals markets, gold is on course for its largest percentage rise in two years as the softer USD and buying ahead of the Chinese Lunar New year dictated a bulk of the price action. Elsewhere, copper has also benefited from the aforementioned currency swings and global manufacturing picture with prices on track for their largest gain in over a year.

subject: Vale (VALE) reports Q4 Iron-ore production at 93.4mln tons
FX LATEST: some relative Usd strength
content: Market contacts note a bit of nibbling in the DXY helping to nudge the Index back over 88.400 (just), and this has filtered through the basket as G10 pairings adjust accordingly. Arguably, Cable prompted the partial Dollar recovery having pulled back from best levels just ahead of the UK retail sales release, and now after to around 1.4080 vs circa 1.4145 at one stage. Eur/Usd is having a look at 1.2500 again, and Usd/Jpy is picking off more offers said to be layered just above 106.00. The looming long US holiday weekend does offer the Greenback some further respite on short covering grounds, but it remains to be seen whether it can stop the rot and regain its early February recovery momentum or if the end-2017 into January bear trend has returned with a vengeance.

subject: ECB's Coeure said to discuss policy language in early 2018
ECB’s Coeure says interest rates will not rise before bond buying ends; also stating that policy makers are unanimous
Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) January group deliveries up 10.1% to 898.7K vehicles
EU MID-SESSION UPDATE: USD remains the driving force in FX. EU bourses higher in a busy morning of earnings. UK retail sales disappoint

subject: ASIA-PAC SERVICE HAS NOW FINISHED, PLEASE REVERT BACK TO YOUR ORIGINAL CHANNEL FOR COVERAGE ON THE UK & EUROPEAN SESSION
Gilts and Short Sterling futures: some short covering ahead of UK retail sales data
content: UK debt deriving support from a firmer rebound in Bunds (up to 157.97, +8 ticks vs -23 ticks at worst) and some corrective price action after a flat start to Friday’s Liffe session and fleeting dip to 120.57 vs yesterday’s 120.59 close. The 10 year benchmark climbed to 120.77 before losing momentum and looks set for some sideways consolidation ahead of the ONS retail sales data given the consensus for a decent rebound after December’s very weak consumption report (albeit heavily skewed by seasonal factors and on-line promotions). Indeed, the 3 month strip is treading more cautiously just 1 tick either side of parity in paltry volume.

subject: ECB says banks borrowed EUR 53mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 687.2bln
Morning EU Movers: EDF (EDF FP) + 4.4%, Renault (RNO FP) +4.2%, Segro (SGRO LN) +3.2%, ENI (ENI SM) +2%, Danone (BN FP) +1%, Vivendi (VIV FP) -3.8%, SAAB (SSAB SS) -6%
Bunds: downtrend resumes after mild recovery late yesterday
content: Thursday’s short covering rebound amidst further yield curve flattening has stalled, again, with the 10 year German debt future unable to recapture the 158.00 level or maintain a rebound above tech resistance levels around the big figure before ending the Eurex session at 157.88. Hence, the overall bear trend remains intact and Bunds have retreated to 157.66 so far awaiting more direction and opportunities to sell. As usual German wholesale prices did not really impact despite a significant beat vs expectations in m/m terms and the data slate is blank ahead, but ECB’s Coeure may provide some impetus ahead of several US releases in the pm session. However, core EU debt continues to take its main cues from US Treasury counterparts that have paused just before the next key levels in futures, and perhaps more importantly in yields, ie 10 year just shy of 2.95% on course for 3%?

subject: Japan's Chief Govt. spokesman said the FX market has shown one-sided moves recently
content:
- He added no need to change government stance on FX

- No comments were added on whether appropriate measures include FX intervention

subject: Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
Cellnex Telecom (CLNX SM) – FY 2017 EBITDA EUR 355mln vs. Exp. EUR 353.4mln, revenue EUR 792mln vs. Prev. Y/Y EUR 707mln and FY 2017 net EUR 33mln vs. Exp. EUR 45.7mln. (Newswires)

Segro (SGRO LN) – Co reports pre-tax profit GBP 976.3mln vs Prev. GBP 426.4mln. FY EPRA NAV per share +16.3% to GBP 5.56 vs. Prev. GBP 4.78. FY adj. EPS +5.9% to GBP 0.2 vs. Prev. GBP 0.19. (Newswires)

Balfour Beatty (BBY LN) – Co. joint venture awarded a USD 1.95bln contract. (Newswires)

Nibe Industrier (NIBEB SS) – FY17 sales +23.9% to SEK 19.009bln vs. Prev. SEK 15.348bln.  2017 profits after net financial items +16.6% to SEK 2.182bln vs. Prev. 1.871bln. Co. says proposed dividend of SEK 1.05/shr vs. Prev. SEK 0.88/shr. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – CEO says media report on the replacement of Audi head Stadler are false. (Newswires)

INDITEX (ITX SM) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT DZ BANK

CREDIT SUISSE (CSGN SW) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT DZ BANK

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include earnings from Allianz, Renault, EDF, Air France and Danone
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

16th February 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Stock markets were quiet in Asia with most the region away for Lunar New Year holiday, while the few bourses which were open seemed to have joined in on the celebratory tone and initially took impetus from a 5th consecutive win streak on Wall St. As such, ASX 200 (-0.1%) was positive for most the day with earnings in focus, although upside was capped and later reversed amid profit taking in mining-related sectors. Nikkei 225 (+1.3%) continued to defy the recent JPY strength and outperformed as participants widely anticipated the Japanese government nominations for Kuroda to serve a 2nd term and 2 more doves for the Deputy Governor roles, while markets in China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Singapore were among the mass holiday closures.

FTSE

Vodafone (VOD LN) – Co. CEO expects merger with Idea Cellular (IDEA IS) to save substantially more than the previously estimated USD 10bln. (Newswires)

Booker (BOK LN) / Tesco (TSCO LN) – The Institutional Shareholder Services advisory firm has suggested Booker’s investors to oppose the planned merger with Tesco, as concerns about the financial value of the deal emerged. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Allianz (ALV GY) -  Q4 net EUR 1.52bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.43bln, operating profit EUR 2.76bln vs. Prev. EUR 3bln, FY operating profit +0.4% to EUR 11.1bln, total revenues +3% to EUR 126.1bln and proposes a 5% dividend increase. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – HNA have further reduced their stake in the Co. 8.88% from 9.2%. (FT)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Renault (RNO FP) – 2017 revenue +14.7% to EUR 58.77bln vs Exp. EUR 59.25bln. Operating profit +17.4% to EUR 3.854bln vs. Exp. EUR 3.65bln. 2017 net income +49.6% to EUR 5.114bln. Co. intends to keep Carlos Ghosn as CEO. (FT)

Vivendi (VIV FP) – FY adj. net EUR 1.31bln vs. Prev. EUR 755mln, EBITA EUR 987mln vs. Prev. EUR 724mln and revenue EUR 12.4bln vs. Prev. EUR 10.8bln. (Newswires)

EDF (EDF FP) – FY 2017 adj. Net EUR 2.80bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.9bln, EBITDA EUR 13.7bln vs. Exp. EUR 13.7bln and revenue fell 2% to EUR 70bln. (Newswires)

Air France (AF FP) – 2017 Revenues EUR 25.78bln vs. Exp. EUR 25.86bln. 2017 operating results EUR 1.488bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.53bln. 2017 net loss EUR 274mln due to EUR 1.4bln charge to de-risk two pension plans. Q1 unit revenues expected to be positive against last year. (Newswires)

Danone (BN FP) – FY 2017 operating profit EUR 3.54bln vs. Exp. EUR 3.53bln, revenue EUR 24.7bln vs. Exp. EUR 24.7bln and FY 2017 net EUR 2.45bln vs. Prev. EUR 1.72bln. Raises dividend by 11.8%. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Bollore (BOL FP) – FY revenue EUR 18.3bln vs Prev. EUR 10.1bln. (Newswires)

Eutelsat (ETL FP) – H1 net EUR 156.5mln vs. Prev. EUR 192.2mln, revenue EUR 697mln vs. Prev. EUR 755mln. (Newswires)

Faurecia (EO FP) – FY17 net profits EUR 714.5mln vs. Prev. EUR 532.5mln Y/Y. Operating profits EUR 1.17bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.14bln. Revenue EUR 16.9bln vs. Prev. EUR 15.6bln Y/Y. Co. raises dividend by 22% to EUR 1.10/shr. Co. affirms 2018 net cash flow guidance EUR 500mln and EPS EUR 5. Guides initial FY18 sales +7% Y/Y. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

AIRBUS (AIR FP) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM SELL AT LANDESBANK BADEN-WURTTEMBERG

PAN-EUROPE

Vopak (VPK NA) – FY17 net profit EUR 287.4mln vs. Prev. EUR 326.1mln Y/Y. Adj. EBITDA EUR 763.2mln vs. Prev. EUR 822.3mln Y/Y. Revenue EUR 1.35bl1bln vs. Prev. EUR 1.35bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Altice (ATC NA) – Portugal’s competition authority reported on Thursday to launch an investigation into the acquisition by Dutch-based Altice of Media Capital who owns the TVI tv channel. (Newswires)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – Co. are looking for binding offers for Persidera this weekend. (Newswires)

ENI (ENI IM) – Q4 adj. net EUR 975mln vs. Exp. EUR 577mln and adj. operating profit EUR 2bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.93bln. (Newswires)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – The Italian antitrust authority reported on Thursday to be investigating Italy’s TIM, Vodafone, Fastweb and Wind Tre on fear of anti-competitive billing practices. (Newswires)

Mediaset (MS IM) – Vivendi’s CEO reported on Thursday to be hopeful in finding an agreement with the Co. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ENEL IM (ENEL IM) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT LANDESBANK BADEN-WURTTEMBERG

SMI

Roche (ROG SW) – The co. is to acquire Flatiron Health for USD 1.9bln. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

Schindler Holdings (SCHN SW) – FY17 net profits CHF 884mln vs. Prev. CHF 823mln Y/Y. EBIT CHF 1.19bln vs. Prev. CHF 1.13bln Y/Y. Revenue CHF 10.18bln vs. Exp. CHF 10.15bln. Orders CHF 10.9bln vs. Prev. CHF 10.4bln. Guides initial FY18 revenue +3% to +5%. Co. appoints Urs Scheideggers as CFO effective 1st Aprill.  (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CLARIANT (CLN SW) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT CREDIT SUISSE

SCANDINAVIA

Norsk Hydro (NHY NO) – Q4 underlying EBIT NOK 3.555bln vs. Exp. NOK 3.79bln. Co. proposes 2017 dividend NOK 1.75/shr vs. Exp. NOK 1.48/shr. (Newswires)

SAAB (SSAB SS) – Q4 revenue SEK 9.82bln vs. Exp. SEK 9.79bln, operating profit SEK 882mln vs. Prev. SEK 960mln, Q4 EPS SEL 4.81 vs. Prev. SEK 5.82. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

US

EQUITIES: SPX +1.21% at 2731 , DJI +1.23% at 25200, NDX +1.8% at 6795

Top performers: Utilities +1.75%, Tech +1.72%, Industrials +1.23%

Bottom performers: Energy -0.50%, Financials +0.47%, Cons Cyclicals +0.52%

 

The emini extended gains for a fifth day, continuing to pare-back losses incurred after the volatility-induced slide. The March contract rose to highs above 2725, after breaking through the 2720 resistance level (now turned support). Grinding out gains is proving tough work, and the contract remains around 5% off highs near 2785. Traders continued to cite the healthy landscape of corporate America (solid earnings, fiscal reform boost, etc), and decent prospects for global growth as the driver. In terms of sectors, tech and industrials were leading; Apple was higher after Berkshire Hathaway made the company its top investment, while Cisco’s results released on Wednesday were received well. Energy was the laggard, after crude softness in early trade. The VIX, meanwhile remains under the 20 handle.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Stock markets were quiet in Asia with most the region away for Lunar New Year holiday. Nikkei outperformed post-BoJ appointments
content:
• Stock markets were quiet in Asia with most the region away for Lunar New Year holiday. Nikkei outperformed post-BoJ appointments
  • In FX, the greenback gave further ground to its major counterparts
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK retail sales, US building permits, housing starts Uni. Of Michigan

ASIA

Stock markets were quiet in Asia with most the region away for Lunar New Year holiday, while the few bourses which were open seemed to have joined in on the celebratory tone and initially took impetus from a 5th consecutive win streak on Wall St. As such, ASX 200 (-0.1%) was positive for most the day with earnings in focus, although upside was capped and later reversed amid profit taking in mining-related sectors. Nikkei 225 (+1.3%) continued to defy the recent JPY strength and outperformed as participants widely anticipated the Japanese government nominations for Kuroda to serve a 2nd term and 2 more doves for the Deputy Governor roles, while markets in China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Singapore were among the mass holiday closures. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher as Japanese yields retreated across the curve and which also followed the gains in USTs during the prior session, while the enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated bonds failed to impact prices with the results broadly inline with the prior.

Japan submitted nomination for BoJ Governor Kuroda to stay on for another term, while it also nominated reflationist academic Wakatabe and BoJ’s Amamiya as Deputy Governors. (Newswires)


UK/EU

UK government is reportedly prepared to lay out its post-Brexit vision for the financial services sector. (Newswires)

The UK’s IOD has put forward a bespoke Brexit solution which it believes will protect manufacturers from customs chaos but also allow the UK to strike independent trade deals. (Telegraph)

Norwegian Central Bank Governor Olsen said may hike interest rates this year and that the NOK exchange rate puts limits on how far rates can deviate from other countries. (Newswires)
 

FX

FX markets were initially uneventful amid the holiday-quietened conditions, until the greenback gave further ground to its major counterparts in which EUR/USD and GBP/USD gained a firmer footing at the 1.2500 and 1.4100 handles respectively. Elsewhere. USD/JPY ignored Kuroda’s nomination for a 2nd term as this was widely expected, and instead saw a fall-out from the USD-weakness as stops were triggered on a break below the 106.00 level for the first time since 2016, which also pressured JPY-crosses in tandem.

COMMODITIES

Commodities saw mild gains overnight as the weakness in the greenback continued to underpin prices, with WTI crude futures edging closer towards a retest of the USD 62/bbl level where it encountered resistance last week. Elsewhere, gold is on course for its best weekly performance since 2016 due to the softer USD and firmer US inflation, while copper also saw marginal upside amid the heightened global risk appetite despite the absence of its largest consumer China.

White House Legislative Director Short said there is no support for a gas tax hike in Congress. (Newswires)


US

The surge higher in yields paused on Thursday, with buyers emerging as 10-year yields rose above 2.90% (2.94% was the HOD). Today’s data slate (PPI, industrial production, Philly Fed, weekly jobless claims) had little influence on price action, with the narrative still fixed on inflationary pressures following the January payrolls data which signalled wages were firming, and January’s CPI data released this week, that surprised to the upside; yesterday’s retail sales missed was being explained away as a blip following retail inventories being drawn down strongly, leaving retailers with little need to slash prices in January sales, perhaps explaining the weakness in the January retail sales data. The US Treasury auctioned new 30-year tips, tailing by 1.4bps, though indirect participation was encouraging. The US Treasury announced it will next week auction $28bln in 2s, $35bln in 5s, and $29bln in 7s, as well as $15bln of 2y FRNs. At settlement, The Treasuries were little changed on the day, with most of the action focussed in the long end, where yields fell by just shy of 3bps. T-Note Futures settle 4 ticks higher at 120-14+.

US Treasury announcement: USD 51bln in 3-month bills, USD 45bln in 6 month bills, USD 28bln 2yr Notes, USD 35bln 5yr Notes, USD 29bln 7yr Notes, USD 15bln 2yr FRN. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he is cautiously hopeful that NAFTA will be renegotiated and that the US priority is to renegotiate the deal. In related news, White House confirmed US President Trump will meet Mexico President Pena Nieto, while there were also comments from Mexican NAFTA negotiator who noted 6 to 10 chapters are ready to close but there is still a lot of work to do on autos. (Newswires)

White House urged the House to advance the Goodlatte immigration proposal after 4 bills were defeated in the Senate. (Newswires)

Former Trump campaign adviser Gates is said to be nearing a plea deal with Special Counsel Mueller with negotiations having taken around a month already. (Newswires)]

subject: Japan MoF, FSA and BoJ are to hold a meeting at 1600 local time (0700GMT) regarding international markets
Nikkei 225 closes higher by 1.2% at 21,720
Vodafone (VOD LN) CEO expects merger with Idea Cellular (IDEA IS) to save substantially more than the previously estimated USD 10bln
ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia quiet with most the region on holiday, USD gave up further ground and USD/JPY slipped below the 106.00 handle
content:
Stock markets were quiet in Asia with most the region away for Lunar New Year holiday, while the few bourses which were open seemed to have joined in on the celebratory tone and initially took impetus from a 5th consecutive win streak on Wall St. As such, ASX 200 (-0.1%) was positive for most the day with earnings in focus, although upside was capped and later reversed amid profit taking in mining-related sectors. Nikkei 225 (+1.3%) continued to defy the recent JPY strength and outperformed as participants widely anticipated the Japanese government nominations for Kuroda to serve a 2nd term and 2 more doves for the Deputy Governor roles, while markets in China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Singapore were among the mass holiday closures. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher as Japanese yields retreated across the curve and which also followed the gains in USTs during the prior session, while the enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated bonds failed to impact prices with the results broadly inline with the prior.

FX markets were initially uneventful amid the holiday-quietened conditions, until the greenback gave further ground to its major counterparts in which EUR/USD and GBP/USD gained a firmer footing at the 1.2500 and 1.4100 handles respectively. Elsewhere. USD/JPY ignored Kuroda’s nomination for a 2nd term as this was widely expected, and instead saw a fall-out from the USD-weakness as stops were triggered on a break below the 106.00 level for the first time since 2016, which also pressured JPY-crosses in tandem.

subject: PRE-MARKET INDIAN STOCK NEWS: RBI directed Punjab National Bank to pay the entire amount owed to counterparty banks in the alleged INR 113.9bln fraud
content:
Fortis Healthcare (FORTIS IS)
- India’s top court has paved the way for the sale of Co. shares which was pledged to lenders by former board members Malvinder and Shivinder Singh. (ET)

Punjab National Bank (PNB IS)
- Co. notified BSE about fraud equal to INR 113.9bln, while RBI directed Punjab National Bank to pay the entire amount owed to counterparty banks in the alleged fraud. (Newswires)

Union Bank of India (UNBK IS)
- Co. estimates outstanding exposure to Punjab National Bank (PNB IS) issue of about USD 300mln and is confident it will receive payment. (Newswires)

Financials
- RBI said it stands prepared to inject additional cash into the banking system if required ahead of March-end to aid lenders in managing liquidity heading into end of quarter and fiscal year. (Moneycontrol)

Data Recap
- India Trade Balance (USD)(Jan) -16.3B vs. Exp. -13.0B (Prev. -14.9B). (Newswires)
- India Exports (Jan) Y/Y 9.1% (Prev. 12.4%)
- India Imports (Jan) Y/Y 26.1% (Prev. 21.1%)

subject: White House urges House to advance Goodlatte immigration proposal after 4 bills were defeated in Senate
ASIA-PAC MID SESSION UPDATE: Asia celebrates Lunar New Year
content:
Trade is exceptionally quiet in Asia with most the region away for Lunar New Year holiday, while the few bourses which are open seem to have joined in on the celebratory tone and take impetus from a 5th consecutive win streak on Wall St. As such, ASX 200 (+0.1%) is positive with earnings remaining in focus, although upside is capped amid profit taking in mining-related sectors. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+1.1%) continues to defy the recent JPY strength and outperforms as participants widely anticipated the Japanese government nominations for Kuroda to serve a 2nd term, as well as BoJ’s Amamiya and reflationist academic Wakatabe for the Deputy Governor positions.

FX markets are uneventful amid the holiday-quietened conditions, although the greenback gave further ground to its major counterparts with EUR/USD and GBP/USD trading at the 1.2500 and 1.4100 handles respectively. Elsewhere, AUD/USD is flat after it largely ignored comments from RBA Governor Lowe who reiterated that the most likely next move in rates is up but he doesn't see a strong case for a near-term policy adjustment, while the Japanese government nominations for the BoJ including a 2nd term for Governor Kuroda failed to spur a reaction as this was widely expected.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher as Japanese yields retreat across the curve and which also follows the gains in USTs during the prior session, while focus now shifts to the enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated Japanese bonds later.

subject: Japan submits nomination for BoJ Governor Kuroda for another term, while it also submits nominations for Wakatabe and Amamiya as Deputy Governors

BoJ Governor Kuroda says Japan's economy is expanding moderately but growth in prices remain low
content:
Says:
- BoJ must maintain powerful; easing and that Japan is not yet in a position where BoJ can offer plan on how and when to exit ultra-loose policy.
- When time for exit arrives, BoJ will communicate its tensions in an appropriate manner to avoid market turbulence..
